I think one answer (out of many) is that you want to test one
*behavior* at a time.  With this class, that behavior is that anything
saved with saveLicense() can be loaded with loadLicense(...).  So that
makes good sense (to me) as a single test.

If you had some kind of requirement that things written with
saveLicense have a particular format, or that loadLicense expects a
particular format (for 3rd party integration or something), then you'd
have more behaviors and probably want to make separate tests.  Even in
that case, though, testing that stuff saved with saveLicense can be
loaded with loadLicense isn't a bad thing to do.

$.02

Kevin

> Given that I have two methods of my class I need to test, SaveLicense
> and LoadLicense, should I write this as two separate tests or as a 
> single test that incorporates both? To clarify, to load a license, I 
> would need to have a saved license. The load license would then
verify 
> that the information that was saved was loaded correctly.
